title: Plural form -lar and -ler in Turkish
desc: Plural form of nouns in Turkish

body.raw:
# Plurals in Turkish - √áokluk Eki
---

Let us take a look at how we can make words plural. It is the same like English in the sense that it comes at the end of the word.

The letters that correspond `s` , `es` or `ies` in English for plurality are **lar** and ********ler.********

Let us see this in play. 

<aside>
üí° 
Car        ‚Üí     Car**s**                                Flower   ‚Üí  Flowers
Araba    ‚Üí     Araba******lar******                         √ái√ßek     ‚Üí  √ái√ßek******ler******

</aside>

You might be wondering when do we use **************ler**************  and when do we use **********lar**********?

In Turkish, for ease of pronunciation we pay attention to the **last vowel** of the word being in harmony with the **suffix** added. 

<aside>
üí° 
üìå If the last vowel is either `a` , `ƒ±` ,`o` ,`u` then ********lar******** is added to the word to make it plural. 

üìå If the last vowel is either `e`, `i`, `√∂` `√º` then **ler** is added to the word to make it plural.

</aside>

|        Last Vowel |           Plural suffix |
| --- | --- |
| a-ƒ±-o-u | -lar |
| e-i-√∂-√º | -ler |

That‚Äôs why Cars is Arab**alar** and Flowers is √ái√ß**e**k******ler.******

### Using ‚Äúler‚Äù and ‚Äúlar‚Äù with Numbers

When a word is preceded by a number in Turkish, we **do not** use the suffixes -**lar** and -**ler.**

<aside>
üí° 
Five Books  

‚Üí Be≈ü kitaplar ‚ùå

‚Üí Be≈ü kitap     ‚úÖ

Why is that?
It is because the number **be≈ü** is already indicates its plural and to avoid redundancy.

</aside>

üìå
You will probably be like d√∂rt arabalar when you should instead say d√∂rt araba.It takes conscious  effort to avoid it.

---
